title: DIY vs Professional Epoxy Floor Coating: What You Need to Know
excerpt: Thinking about DIY epoxy? Learn why professional installation often saves money long-term and delivers superior results for your garage floor.

children.text: With DIY epoxy kits readily available at home improvement stores, many homeowners wonder if they can save money by coating their garage floors themselves. While the upfront cost is lower, the reality is that most DIY epoxy projects fail within 1-2 years, leading to costly re-dos.

The #1 reason DIY epoxy fails is inadequate surface preparation. Most homeowners don't have access to professional diamond grinding equipment needed to properly profile the concrete. Without proper preparation, even the best epoxy won't adhere correctly.

• Peeling and delamination within 6-12 months
• Hot tire pickup in summer heat
• Poor adhesion over oil stains
• Inconsistent coverage and appearance
• No warranty or professional support

Professional epoxy installation includes proper surface preparation using diamond grinding equipment, premium 100% solids epoxy (not water-based), proper application techniques, and comprehensive warranties. The result is a floor that lasts 10-15 years instead of 1-2.

title: How to Maintain Your Epoxy Garage Floor for Maximum Lifespan
excerpt: Simple maintenance tips to keep your epoxy garage floor looking great and lasting 15+ years. Learn what to do and what to avoid.

children.text: Your new epoxy garage floor is an investment that should last 10-15 years or more with proper care. While epoxy floors are incredibly durable and low-maintenance, following these simple guidelines will ensure maximum lifespan and keep your floor looking like new.

Clean up spills immediately - while epoxy resists stains, it's always best to wipe up oil, antifreeze, or other automotive fluids quickly. For regular cleaning, simply sweep or vacuum debris, then damp mop with warm water and a mild detergent.

• Abrasive cleaners or scrubbers
• Citrus-based cleaners
• Vinegar or acidic solutions
• Steel wool or metal scrapers
• High-pressure washing (can damage edges)
